column4: Hi, I'm awesomely confused -- can someone please tell me: is it bad to have /home on its own partition (say 200GB) and / on its own partition (say 30 GB) ?
disk usage analyzer reveeals that its full (100%) and the largest thing inside of it is home directory (90%)
also make shure to unckeck the option that backups on home directory if bacckup location isn't available
it may be on a hidden folder
the backup? in a hidden foler on the external drive?
in a hidden folder in you home
try logging in in a tty and running du * -sH | less
try logging in in a tty and running du .* -sH | less
I'm booted into the laptop from a CD  -- I tried `du ./* -sH | sort -r | less` and the biggest stuff (coming up at the top) is music folder contents.
that command was for running in the installed os
fron the liveCD you can use baobab to know which is the biggest folder

baobab reveals the same thing it did before I had rebooted: the /home direcotry is biggest, nad te biggest pocket of space in the /home directory is a tar in one of the user's ~/downloads directory. (its not my backup) --
any clue what I should try? http://paste.ubuntu.com/381831/
guntbert: jrib: this is my df -ah output, any ideas? http://paste.ubuntu.com/381834/ (thanks guntbert)
mount your /
and go to your home folder in the terminal (with cd)
once you're there type  du -hs .*

guntbert: jrib: it looks like baobab is showing differnt things than the command line isshowing, so I'm just going to stick to the command line? i guess? -- doing: sudo du -s /media/8ec.../*reveals about15 paths, butnone of them are the backup file.
just type: du -hs .*              in your home folder and pastebin it
du -hs .* | sort -r | less revealed an 8M .mozilla to be the biggest
okay, just a sec.
I'm talking about your home partition
this is my home partition:http://paste.ubuntu.com/381842/ and this is my /home/bridget partition (the one I was in when I ran the backup): http://paste.ubuntu.com/381841/
:) thanks for the help
